text: it started with an undersea earthquake
one of the biggest in recorded history
that triggered a tsunami which by the
time it came ashore here in the
Indonesian province of Aceh was a wave
maybe 20 maybe 30 meters high it hit the
shore at about 8 o'clock in the morning
and it kept on going it pushed miles
inland heading towards the regional
capital Banda Aceh it smashed into the
first houses and kept going by the time
it had finished maybe a hundred and
sixty thousand people were dead or dying
the entire city had more or less being
destroyed a decade later and as you
might expect the city has made a
dramatic recovery there's no hint really
here of the scars left by the tsunami
the place is bustling and it's peaceful
it's important to remember that there
used to be a terrible separatist
conflict here in akshay the tsunami had
a catalytic effect ending that conflict
almost immediately and the peace is
still holding here one result of that is
that actually is now more autonomous
which means that there is Sharia law
which has been imposed with increasing
strictness some people like that they
feel that the tsunami was a punishment
from God but other people are worried
that Sharia law is starting to scare
away the foreign investment many here
believe this province badly needs I've
come to a multi-story escape building
one of several built here along the
coastline
just in case another tsunami should
strike actually and you get a sense from
up here of how the seven billion dollars
raised after the tsunami by the
international community has been spent I
remember coming to this port area of
lele just after the tsunami there was
nothing here every tree every building
had been destroyed and now look at it
these are some of the 140,000 homes
built by the international community
since the tsunami
no not all of them are occupied yes some
of them are more safe more well built
than others but overall it's been a
success of 2,000 miles three and a half
thousand kilometers of new roads built
as well and when you talk to people here
in Banda Aceh in particular nobody is
going to forget for a second what
happened but overall pretty much
everyone says that their lives their
economy is better now than it was before
the tsunami
